comments:
The UML2Util::getMessageSubstitution(Map context, Object object) method assumes
that if the context map does not include an
EValidator.SubstitutionLabelProvider, then it will have a QualifiedTextProvider.
 The result is a null-pointer exception if neither of these is provided.

It would be nice to fall back to a default qualified-text provider that just
uses NamedElement::getQualifiedName() or some such.

To reproduce:

---- snippet ----
org.eclipse.uml2.Class cls = UML2Factory.eINSTANCE.createClass();
Actor actor = UML2Factory.eINSTANCE.createActor();

// classes may not own specialize actors
cls.createGeneralization(actor);

// throws NullPointerException
cls.validateSpecializeType(
    new BasicDiagnostic("", 0, "", new Object[0]),
    Collections.EMPTY_MAP);
---- end snippet ----

---- stack trace ----
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at org.eclipse.uml2.util.UML2Util.appendQualifiedTextSegment(UML2Util.java:5244)
	at org.eclipse.uml2.util.UML2Util.appendQualifiedText(UML2Util.java:5236)
	at org.eclipse.uml2.util.UML2Util.getQualifiedText(UML2Util.java:5217)
	at org.eclipse.uml2.util.UML2Util.getMessageSubstitution(UML2Util.java:5485)
	at org.eclipse.uml2.util.UML2Util.getMessageSubstitutions(UML2Util.java:5510)
	at
org.eclipse.uml2.internal.operation.ClassifierOperations.validateSpecializeType(ClassifierOperations.java:173)
	at
org.eclipse.uml2.impl.ClassifierImpl.validateSpecializeType(ClassifierImpl.java:1192)
---- end stack trace ----
The fix has been committed to CVS.
The fix is available in build 1.1RC1.
